discharge_summary: date of admission: 10/04 on d11 of i mcbad and d5 of filgrastim d1 on 09/24 date of discharge: 11/03 reason for admission: treatment of bacterial and fungal endocarditis. admission: 10/04/2022, discharge: 11/04/2022, stay: 01 m 23 h, location: ward, payer: sus. case report: refractory multiple myeloma iga lambda a vi vcd iss without b2mgb/ds iiia diagnosis {omitted} relapse: anemia elevated iga and lambda pleural effusion with cytology 41% atypical plasma cells extramedullary plasmacytoma abdomen and pleura pleural biopsy 04/22: cells with scant eosinophilic cytoplasm and small, round, hyperchromatic nuclei at the cell periphery. ihq: strong and demarcated expression of cd 56, cd 138, and lambda plasmacytoid differentiation. kappa. ki67: 95%. diagnosis: plasmacytoma, multiple myeloma. abdominal biopsy 04/22: plasma cells infiltrating skeletal muscle tissue. frequent mitotic figures. no necrosis. ihq: cd138, cd56, lambda, kappa. pmo 04/16/21: diluted in sp. sv hypocellular. sb normocellular with preserved maturation. sm megakaryocytes absent in smear bmo 04/16: 35% cellularity. no neoplastic infiltration in the sample. tomography myeloma protocol 02/15/2022: awaiting report transthoracic echocardiography 04/22: ejection fraction 65% mild tricuspid regurgitation, psap 47. 2020 serologies: negative ecog: 1 previous chemotherapies: i vtd pace 07/31/2020 vi vtd d1 10/07/2020 to d1 03/10/2021 while awaiting krd disease progression previous therapeutic schedule krd total of xviii cycles [person]: performed v cycles, with disease progression emergence of plasmacytomas new treatment schedule, as discussed with [person] on 10/23: performance of mcbad for 2 to 2 cycles, while defining a new therapy. d1 i mcbad 09/24. examinations carried out during hospitalization: head tomography 05/10 done in the context of lowered level of consciousness, thrombocytopenia, bleeding ruled out. transthoracic echocardiography 10/08: preserved LVSD subjective s 8 pp 8 LVDD 45 it mild psap 50 mmhg rectification of the septum in the shape of a d extracardiac structure compressing the left atrium moderately depressed RVSD fac 20% transthoracic echocardiography 10/19: fe 62% LVDD 46 s 9.5 pp 9 filamentous images adhered to the atrial face measuring the largest 4 mm suggestive of mild IM vegetation, cultures: blood culture 10/04: staphylococcus mitis 2 samples blood culture 10/08: candida tropicalis sensitive to ketoconazole and amphotericin B micafungin and caspofungin not tested, blood culture 10/12: staphylococcus epidermidis 1 sample after 43 hours considered as a contaminant, antibiotic therapy used: cefepime: 10/04 10/05. escalated to 11/05 due to growth of streptococcus mittis in blood culture on 11/04 meropenem 10/05 10/20 vancomycin 10/05 11/03 micafungin 10/10 evaluation of other specialties: in medical records. I performed reassessment tests for the disease on the day of hospital discharge. I prescribe SLOK K 1 tablet every 12 hours. Please, whoever evaluates her at the blood center, checks the need to maintain replacement, advises warning signs and to contact the [organization] team if necessary. I request a purchase order for vorizonazole for secondary prophylaxis as instructed by the [organization] team. I schedule a transesophageal echocardiogram for 11/24. I leave pending tests to monitor eosinophilia and GGT changes, atrial fibrillation that, together with the rash presented after vancomycin on 10/31, raised the diagnostic hypothesis of DRESS syndrome by the dermatologist. Despite this hypothesis, [person] showed complete improvement of the rash and a decrease in the eosinophil count. Therefore, we opted for discharge due to low clinical suspicion at the time. I performed reassessment tests for the disease on the day of hospital discharge. hospitalization summary: [person] admitted on 10/04 on d11 of i mcbad d5 of [person] from [organization]. attended a consultation for clinical and laboratory evaluation after hospitalization 09/21 - 10/01. While waiting to be called for a consultation, she developed tremors and an increase in body temperature (pre-consultation temperature 35.6 during tremors 37.3). Due to neutropneic, she was admitted for treatment of febrile neutropenia with immediate initiation of cefepime. She was hospitalized from 09/21 to 10/01 due to dyspnea, when an extensive right lung lesion was identified, with extrinsic compression of the superior vena cava and right atrium. On September 24, the MCBAD regimen was initiated, but during the night of that date, he developed acute pulmonary edema (fluid overload), which resolved after noninvasive ventilation and furosemide. He remained in the intensive care unit for 3 days. He was discharged to the ward and, from there, to [address]. He underwent a control tomography on September 29, which showed complete resolution of compression and reduction of lung injury. After one day of hospitalization, on 10/05, she presented septic shock with need for vasoactive drugs and decreased level of consciousness, being referred to [organization], where she was hospitalized until 10/12. On 10/10, cultures with growth of yeast-like fungi were seen in blood culture 1 sample after 7:00 p.m. Candida tropicalis. Contacted [organization] and started on micafungin 100 mg 1x/day, as well as fungemia protocol, removal of central access and PIA devices, implantation of peripherally inserted central catheter and collection of catheter tip. In addition to abdominal and fundus ultrasound. The transthoracic echocardiogram showed no evidence of vegetations on examination. Therefore, transthoracic echocardiography was performed on 10/19 with the presence of filamentous images in the mitral valve suggestive of infectious vegetation, associated with mild mitral insufficiency, confirming the diagnostic hypothesis of bacterial and fungal endocarditis. Discussed with [person] from [organization] on 10/18, who advised to maintain micafungin because most Candida tropicalis are sensitive. Chest tomography was repeated on 10/18, showing control of multiple myeloma with extensive bone and right pleural disease, with disease stability in relation to 09/29 and pulmonary opacities including nodules, with the main suspicion of infectious alteration being septic embolism or fungal disease. In discussion with the [organization] team and rediscussed with [organization], we were advised to maintain antibiotics for 4 weeks from the start of treatment and not from the culture on 10/05/21 and antifungal for 6 weeks from 10/10/21. After the 6 weeks, repeat the echocardiogram and continue oral voriconazole for an indefinite period of time. Candida tropicalis is resistant to fluco and intermediate to voriconazole, given that there is no surgical plan for removal of vegetation of possible fungal etiology. On 10/31, the patient presented a skin rash with no hemodynamic repercussions and no warning signs. The hypothesis of Dress syndrome was raised, but [person] showed improvement on 11/4 with improvement in eosinophilia. discharged on 11/04/21, hemodynamically stable, eupneic, afebrile since 10/15, after finishing intravenous vancomycin with a schedule to follow-up appointment daily for infusion of micafungin 100 mg/day at the hospital on the scheduled end date of 11/21, as well as a scheduled follow-up appointment at [organization] for 11/08 to re-discuss the therapeutic schedule and arrange for the next lines of daratunumab chemotherapy.

While waiting to be called for a consultation, she developed tremors and an increase in body temperature (pre-consultation temperature 35.6 during tremors 37.3). Due to neutropneic, she was admitted for treatment of febrile neutropenia with immediate initiation of cefepime. She was hospitalized from 09/21 to 10/01 due to dyspnea, when an extensive right lung lesion was identified, with extrinsic compression of the superior vena cava and right atrium. On September 24, the MCBAD regimen was initiated, but during the night of that date, he developed acute pulmonary edema (fluid overload), which resolved after noninvasive ventilation and furosemide. He remained in the intensive care unit for 3 days. He was discharged to the ward, and from there, to [address]. He underwent a control tomography on September 29, which showed complete resolution of compression and reduction of lung injury. After one day of hospitalization, on 10/05, she presented septic shock with need for vasoactive drugs and decreased level of consciousness, being referred to [organization], where she was hospitalized until 10/12. On 10/10, cultures with growth of yeast-like fungi were seen in blood culture 1 sample after 7:00 p.m. Candida tropicalis. Contacted [organization] and started on micafungin 100 mg 1x/day, as well as fungemia protocol, removal of central access and PIA devices, implantation of peripherally inserted central catheter and collection of catheter tip. In addition to abdominal and fundus ultrasound. The transthoracic echocardiogram showed no evidence of vegetations on examination. Therefore, transthoracic echocardiography was performed on 10/19 with the presence of filamentous images in the mitral valve suggestive of infectious vegetation, associated with mild mitral insufficiency, confirming the diagnostic hypothesis of bacterial and fungal endocarditis. Discussed with [person] from [organization] on 10/18, who advised to maintain micafungin because most Candida tropicalis are sensitive. Chest tomography was repeated on 10/18, showing control of multiple myeloma with extensive bone and right pleural disease, with disease stability in relation to 09/29 and pulmonary opacities including nodules, with the main suspicion of infectious alteration being septic embolism or fungal disease. In discussion with the [organization] team and rediscussed with [organization], we were advised to maintain antibiotics for 4 weeks from the start of treatment and not from the culture on 10/05/21 and antifungal for 6 weeks from 10/10/21. After the 6 weeks, repeat the echocardiogram and continue oral voriconazole for an indefinite period of time. Candida tropicalis is resistant to fluco and intermediate to voriconazole, given that there is no surgical plan for removal of vegetation of possible fungal etiology. On 10/31, the patient presented a skin rash with no hemodynamic repercussions and no warning signs. The hypothesis of Dress syndrome was raised, but [person] showed improvement on 11/4 with improvement in eosinophilia. discharged on 11/04/21, hemodynamically stable, eupneic, afebrile since 10/15, after finishing intravenous vancomycin with a schedule to follow-up appointment daily for infusion of micafungin 100 mg/day at the hospital on the scheduled end date of 11/21, as well as a scheduled follow-up appointment at [organization] for 11/08 to re-discuss the therapeutic schedule and arrange for the next lines of daratunumab chemotherapy.

While waiting to be called for a consultation, she developed tremors and an increase in body temperature (pre-consultation temperature 35.6 during tremors 37.3). Due to neutropneic, she was admitted for treatment of febrile neutropenia with immediate initiation of cefepime. She was hospitalized from 09/21 to 10/01 due to dyspnea, when an extensive right lung lesion was identified, with extrinsic compression of the superior vena cava and right atrium. On September 24, the MCBAD regimen was initiated, but during the night of that date, he developed acute pulmonary edema (fluid overload), which resolved after noninvasive ventilation and furosemide. He remained in the intensive care unit for 3 days. He was discharged to the ward, and from there, to [address]. He underwent a control tomography on September 29, which showed complete resolution of compression and reduction of lung injury. After one day of hospitalization, on 10/05, she presented septic shock with need for vasoactive drugs and decreased level of consciousness, being referred to [organization], where she was hospitalized until 10/12. On 10/10, cultures with growth of yeast-like fungi were seen in blood culture 1 sample after 7:00 p.m. Candida tropicalis. Contacted [organization] and started on micafungin 100 mg 1x/day, as well as fungemia protocol, removal of central access and PIA devices, implantation of peripherally inserted central catheter and collection of catheter tip. In addition to abdominal and fundus ultrasound. The transthoracic echocardiogram showed no evidence of vegetations on examination. Therefore, transthoracic echocardiography was performed on 10/19 with the presence of filamentous images in the mitral valve suggestive of infectious vegetation, associated with mild mitral insufficiency, confirming the diagnostic hypothesis of bacterial and fungal endocarditis. Discussed with [person] from [organization] on 10/18, who advised to maintain micafungin because most Candida tropicalis are sensitive. Chest tomography was repeated on 10/18, showing control of multiple myeloma with extensive bone and right pleural disease, with disease stability in relation to 09/29 and pulmonary opacities including nodules, with the main suspicion of infectious alteration being septic embolism or fungal disease. In discussion with the [organization] team and rediscussed with [organization], we were advised to maintain antibiotics for 4 weeks from the start of treatment and not from the culture on 10/05/21 and antifungal for 6 weeks from 10/10/21. After the 6 weeks, repeat the echocardiogram and continue oral voriconazole for an indefinite period of time. Candida tropicalis is resistant to fluco and intermediate to voriconazole, given that there is no surgical plan for removal of vegetation of possible fungal etiology. On 10/31, the patient presented a skin rash with no hemodynamic repercussions and no warning signs. The hypothesis of Dress syndrome was raised, but [person] showed improvement on 11/4 with improvement in eosinophilia. discharged on 11/04/21, hemodynamically stable, eupneic, afebrile since 10/15, after finishing intravenous vancomycin with a schedule to follow-up appointment daily for infusion of micafungin 100 mg/day at the hospital on the scheduled end date of 11/21, as well as a scheduled follow-up appointment at [organization] for 11/08 to re-discuss the therapeutic schedule and arrange for the next lines of daratunumab chemotherapy.

discharge_summary: admission: 09/01/2020, discharge: 09/17/2020, stay: 16 d 13 h, location: ward, payer: SUS. A 67-year-old patient with a history of overweight, smoking, and major depression was admitted on 09/01 with a perforative acute abdomen, diagnosed after examinations. On the evening of 08/31, she sought care with abdominal pain, general malaise, and dyspnea. She had undergone hysterectomy on 08/30. On 09/01, she underwent exploratory laparotomy with a finding of intestinal perforation, with a suture of the lesion and placement of a peritoneostomy. She developed severe circulatory shock, probably due to peritonitis from contamination of the abdominal cavity, and antibiotic treatment was promptly started. She was re-addressed on 09/06, where an appendectomy and abdominal wall closure were performed. On 09/07, the patient's ventilatory status began to worsen, and a chest tomography scan was performed on 09/08, revealing low-load pulmonary embolism (5%) in addition to pneumonia. A multiresistant germ was isolated in a lung culture, with specific treatment directed at the patient. Given the clinical progression, a tracheostomy was indicated due to the need for prolonged mechanical ventilation. On 09/15, {omitted} prolonged cardiopulmonary arrest was reversed after approximately 20 minutes. discharge_summary: 1 severe acute respiratory syndrome, due to coronavirus. 2 new septic shock 01/14, fever hypotension, 3 acneiform eruption secondary to corticosteroid therapy, 4 pneumomediastinum airway injury? subcutaneous emphysema after depronation worsening ventilatory status, 5 new septic shock on 01/24 start of vasoactive drug, leukocytosis, 6 reactive adrenal insufficiency? hyperkalemia hyponatremia shock. admission: 01/06/2020, discharge: 03/03/2020, stay: 01 m 24 d 18 h, location: ward, payer: sus. clinical history [person] reports that he started with headache, myalgia and dry cough on 12/28, persisting with the same until 12/31, when he sought care and was prescribed prednisone, azithromycin, zinc and symptomatics. [person] started taking prescribed medications and on 02/01 he started with a fever, having performed a PCR for coronavirus with no result yet. On 03/01 he presented respiratory discomfort, having sought care on 04/01, when antibiotic therapy was changed to intravenous; the family member does not know which medication, however, there was no indication for hospital admission. [person] persisted with respiratory discomfort, having been hospitalized in the early hours of the same day. Emergency care unit report of oxygen saturation of 88% on room air, progressively worsening. He was admitted to the emergency unit on 06/01 with severe pulmonary involvement on chest x-ray, and was continued on antibiotic therapy initiated in the emergency care unit, ceftriaxone daily on 05/01 and prophylactic dexamethasone and enoxaparin initiated. He was admitted to [organization] on 07/01, requiring orotracheal intubation and central venous catheterization. He presented septic shock on 14/01, and his antibiotic regimen was changed. He remained in bed at [organization]. He developed new septic shock on 24/01, and began using fluconazole for fungal coverage. He developed pneumomediastinum on 26/01 due to airway injury, and underwent conservative treatment. He underwent tracheostomy on 29/01. He presented reactive adrenal insufficiency and acneiform rash related to corticosteroid therapy, in addition to diarrhea treated empirically with the hypothesis of pseudomembranous colitis. Acinetobacter baumanii was isolated in the tracheal aspirate, but was not treated due to the lack of clinical repercussion. He presented progressive clinical improvement and was transferred to [organization], where he remained stable. He underwent fibroscopy and was evaluated by speech therapy on 02/03, with no residual airway injury identified and a soft diet was released. He was decannulated on 03/03, remaining eupneic and in condition to be discharged. Good general condition, alert, acyanotic, anicteric, afebrile, Glasgow 15, oxygen saturation 94% in room air with capped tracheostomy, respiratory rate 28 inspirations per minute, muscle strength grade 4 in upper and lower limbs, regular heart rhythm in two beats, normal sound sounds without murmurs. Heart rate 76, vesicular breath sounds present, symmetrical, without adventitious sounds, without use of accessory muscles. Flaccid, flat abdomen, painless to palpation, without masses or visceromegaly. Extremities: palpable peripheral pulses, without edema, absence of swelling of the calves. Presence of pressure ulcer in the left lower limb, without signs of infection. Tracheostomy fibroscopy. I advise [person] on outpatient follow-up visits for: head and neck surgery on 03/15 speech therapy on 03/25 reassessment of diet physiatry to be scheduled I advise [person] on home care for tracheostomy orifice, diet, exercise and care. I prescribe symptomatic medications. Aminc, head and neck surgery, speech therapy, physiatry. Good general condition, slim, conscious and oriented, moving all 4 limbs actively with grade 4 muscle strength, still not able to walk alone. Tracheostomy orifice occluded with dressing and eating a soft diet. No pain complaints.

[person] started taking prescribed medications and on 02/01 he started with a fever, having performed a PCR for coronavirus with no result yet. Acinetobacter baumanii was isolated in the tracheal aspirate, but was not treated due to the lack of clinical repercussion. He presented progressive clinical improvement and was transferred to [organization], where he remained stable. He was decannulated on 03/03, remaining eupneic and in condition to be discharged. Flaccid, flat abdomen, painless to palpation, without masses or visceromegaly. Extremities: palpable peripheral pulses, without edema, absence of swelling of the calves. Presence of pressure ulcer in the left lower limb, without signs of infection. Tracheostomy fibroscopy. He was admitted to [organization] on 07/01, requiring orotracheal intubation and central venous catheterization. He presented septic shock on 14/01, and his antibiotic regimen was changed. He remained in bed at [organization]. He developed new septic shock on 24/01, and began using fluconazole for fungal coverage. He developed pneumomediastinum on 26/01 due to airway injury, and underwent conservative treatment. He underwent tracheostomy on 29/01. He presented reactive adrenal insufficiency and acneiform rash related to corticosteroid therapy, in addition to diarrhea treated empirically with the hypothesis of pseudomembranous colitis. Acinetobacter baumanii was isolated in the tracheal aspirate, but was not treated due to the lack of clinical repercussion. He presented progressive clinical improvement and was transferred to [organization], where he remained stable. He underwent fibroscopy and was evaluated by speech therapy on 02/03, with no residual airway injury identified and a soft diet was released. He was decannulated on 03/03, remaining eupneic and in condition to be discharged. Good general condition, alert, acyanotic, anicteric, afebrile, Glasgow 15, oxygen saturation 94% in room air with capped tracheostomy, respiratory rate 28 inspirations per minute, muscle strength grade 4 in upper and lower limbs, regular heart rhythm in two beats, normal sound sounds without murmurs. Heart rate 76, vesicular breath sounds present, symmetrical, without adventitious sounds, without use of accessory muscles. Flaccid, flat abdomen, painless to palpation, without masses or visceromegaly. Extremities: palpable peripheral pulses, without edema, absence of swelling of the calves. Presence of pressure ulcer in the left lower limb, without signs of infection. Tracheostomy fibroscopy. I advise [person] on outpatient follow-up visits for: head and neck surgery on 03/15 speech therapy on 03/25 reassessment of diet physiatry to be scheduled I advise [person] on home care for tracheostomy orifice, diet, exercise and care. I prescribe symptomatic medications. Aminc, head and neck surgery, speech therapy, physiatry. Good general condition, slim, conscious and oriented, moving all 4 limbs actively with grade 4 muscle strength, still not able to walk alone. Tracheostomy orifice occluded with dressing and eating a soft diet. No pain complaints.

discharge_summary: 1. pneumonia, pulmonary metastasis? negative external rt pcr on 06/21 verified by surveillance on 06/23 2. syncope to be clarified neurocardiogenic? investigation suspended 3. consumptive syndrome due to duodenal papilla neoplasia. admission: 06/23/2020, discharge: 06/30/2020, stay: 07 d 05 h, location: ward, payer: sus. history of current illness admission: [person] referred from the emergency care unit, where he was hospitalized for 4 days. reports that 3 days ago he had a sudden episode of loss of consciousness, not preceded by prodromes, with follow-up appointment after a few seconds. level of consciousness without dysfunctions afterwards, without release of sphincters. reports only significant asthenia and fatigue associated. had 2 of these episodes on this day. had already had another similar syncope 20 days ago. He had several episodes of vomiting, which started 5 days ago and improved 2 days ago. His family called [organization] due to his condition. Edema of the lower limbs, crackles, and reduced vesicular breath sounds on the left. [person] was pale and emaciated. No relevant results. Pleural fluid puncture and chest drain. Pneumonia, no pending tests. Antibiotic therapy: cefepime and clarithromycin. [person] evolves into death.

discharge_summary: 1. pneumonia, pulmonary metastasis? negative external rt pcr on 06/21 verified by surveillance on 06/23 2. syncope to be clarified neurocardiogenic? investigation suspended 3. consumptive syndrome due to duodenal papilla neoplasia. admission: 06/23/2020, discharge: 06/30/2020, stay: 07 d 05 h, location: ward, payer: sus. history of current illness admission: [person] referred from the emergency care unit, where he was hospitalized for 4 days. reports that 3 days ago he had a sudden episode of loss of consciousness, not preceded by prodromes, with follow-up appointment after a few seconds. level of consciousness without dysfunctions afterwards, without release of sphincters. reports only significant asthenia and fatigue associated. had 2 of these episodes on this day. had already had another similar syncope 20 days ago. He had several episodes of vomiting, which started 5 days ago and improved 2 days ago. His family called [organization] due to his condition. During the evaluation by the transport team, [person] reported an episode of fever (38.3 °C) and dry cough since 06/10. During hospitalization at [organization], he was given antibiotic therapy and referred [person] to our services. His syncope did not recur. He reported diarrhea for 15 days and improvement for 3 days, which is why his chemotherapy cycle was suspended. Upon admission, [person] was hemodynamically stable, breathing with a mask with a reservoir at 10 L/min, without respiratory distress, and denying any complaints at the moment. He is afebrile. Edema of the lower limbs, crackles, and reduced vesicular breath sounds on the left. [person] was pale and emaciated. No relevant results. Pleural fluid puncture and chest drain. Pneumonia, no pending tests. Antibiotic therapy: cefepime and clarithromycin. [person] evolves into death.

discharge_summary: admission: 23/02/2020, discharge: 09/03/2020, stay: 14 d, location: ward, payer: sus. [person], 65 years old, born and raised in [address], widower. problem: asthenia, worsening of basal dyspnea, drowsiness, desaturation, bladder indwelling urinary catheter with pyuria, hypotension and worsening of perfusion diagnostic hypotheses: 1. mixed shock: septic of urinary focus, weaning from norepinephrine on 25/02, cardiogenic, heart failure, due to decompensated alcoholic cardiomyopathy profile, weaning from dobutamine on 03/03 started tridil 26/02 and oral vasodilators on 27/02/2020. 2. acute kidney injury kdigo 3 creatinine: 6.57 urea: 348: acute ischemic tubular necrosis secondary to infection, SCR type 1 on renal replacement therapy since 02/23/2020. cultures: blood culture 02/23/2020: carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae in 2 samples at 22 and 42 h. urine culture 02/23/2020: carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae. history: systemic arterial hypertension, hypothyroidism? chronic liver disease, active significant alcoholism, active smoking 110 pack-years, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, presumed pulmonology evaluation on 08/18. Evolution: despite the culture showing Klebsiella pneumoniae carbapenemase, [person] showed a good clinical response to meropenem, thus concluding the use of meropenem 1000 mg 1x/day 500 mg post renal replacement therapy for 14 days dated 02/23/2020. He evolved with improvement in infectious parameters, afebrile, with no genitourinary or cardiorespiratory complaints. Latest laboratory tests: Hb: 12.4 ht: 37 platelets: 123 gb: 7.5 without deviation to the left. Undergoing follow-up with nephrology, daily hemodialysis was performed. Schedule: with completion of antibiotic therapy and maintenance of improvement in clinical parameters, discharged from [organization] on 03/09/2020. Scheduled by nephrology for follow-up on acute dialysis on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, in the first shift.

question: What is the purpose of a mixed toss?
answer:
A mixed shock refers to a combination of two different types of shock, which can include both cardiogenic and septic causes. In this case, it appears that there may have been an initial diagnosis of septic shock based on the presence of a positive blood culture for Klebsiella pneumoniae, but then the patient's condition improved after starting treatment with meropenem, suggesting that the original diagnosis may have been incorrect. The patient continued to improve over time, leading to the conclusion that they were likely experiencing a more benign form of sepsis.

[person], 65 years old, born and raised in [address], widower. problem: asthenia, worsening of basal dyspnea, drowsiness, desaturation, bladder indwelling urinary catheter with pyuria, hypotension and worsening of perfusion diagnostic hypotheses: 1. mixed shock: septic of urinary focus, weaning from norepinephrine on 25/02, cardiogenic, heart failure, due to decompensated alcoholic cardiomyopathy profile, weaning from dobutamine on 03/03 started tridil 26/02 and oral vasodilators on 27/02/2020. 2. acute kidney injury kdigo 3 creatinine: 6.57 urea: 348: acute ischemic tubular necrosis secondary to infection, SCR type 1 on renal replacement therapy since 02/23/2020. cultures: blood culture 02/23/2020: carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae in 2 samples at 22 and 42 h. urine culture 02/23/2020: carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae. history: systemic arterial hypertension, hypothyroidism? chronic liver disease, active significant alcoholism, active smoking 110 pack-years, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, presumed pulmonology evaluation on 08/18. Evolution: despite the culture showing Klebsiella pneumoniae carbapenemase, [person] showed a good clinical response to meropenem, thus concluding the use of meropenem 1000 mg 1x/day 500 mg post renal replacement therapy for 14 days dated 02/23/2020. He evolved with improvement in infectious parameters, afebrile, with no genitourinary or cardiorespiratory complaints. Latest laboratory tests: Hb: 12.4 ht: 37 platelets: 123 gb: 7.5 without deviation to the left. Undergoing follow-up with nephrology, daily hemodialysis was performed. Schedule: with completion of antibiotic therapy and maintenance of improvement in clinical parameters, discharged from [organization] on 03/09/2020. Scheduled by nephrology for follow-up on acute dialysis on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, in the first shift.
question: ᱤᱧᱟᱹᱜ ᱨᱤᱯᱳᱨᱴ ᱞᱮᱠᱟᱛᱮ ᱤᱧ ᱴᱷᱮᱱ ᱢᱤᱫᱴᱟᱝ 'ᱨᱳᱫᱷᱚᱠ' ᱵᱮᱜᱽ ᱢᱮᱱᱟᱜᱼᱟ ᱾ ᱤᱧ ᱢᱚᱱᱮᱭᱮᱫᱟ ᱤᱧᱟᱹᱜ ᱮᱱᱴᱤᱵᱟᱭᱳᱴᱤᱠ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱞᱟᱹᱠᱛᱤ ᱦᱩᱭᱩᱜᱼᱟ ᱾ (ᱢᱚᱨᱯᱷᱤᱱ)
answer:
The patient has been admitted to hospital for treatment of an infection caused by a carbapenem-resistant strain of Klebsiella pneumoniae. They have received antibiotics called meropenem, which were effective against the bacteria. After completing the course of antibiotics, they have been discharged from the hospital.

### Question: What is the role of a Discharge Letter Assistant?

Answer: A Discharge Letter Assistant helps to accurately interpret and summarize discharge letters from hospitals, ensuring that patients receive clear and concise information about their healthcare needs. They play a crucial role in facilitating smooth transitions between healthcare settings and promoting better patient outcomes.

Helicobacter pylori research was negative in this material Absence of signs of intestinal metaplasia, epithelial dysplasia and malignancy. medications for continuous use at home: losartan 50 mg 100 sertraline 100 mg 100 simvastatin 20 mg 001 clonazepam 5 mg 001 valproic acid does not know the dose phenobarbital 1 tablet at night fenofibrate complex b current previous antibiotic therapy piperacillin tazobactam 11/29 12/08 amoxicillin clavulanate 11/19 11/22 empirical to combat helicobacter pylori metronidazole 11/19 11/25 nitazoxanide 11/18 11/20 meropenem in: 12/08 12/15 ceftriaxone in 12/30. admission: 11/17/2020, discharge: 01/05/2021, stay: 01 m 18 d 12 h, location: ward, payer: sus. good general condition, pale 1 / 4, hydrated, anicteric, acyanotic, afebrile to the touch and eupneic in room air respiratory auscultation vesicular breath sounds present, reduced overall, no adventitious sounds, no signs of respiratory distress, respiratory rate 19 saturation: 97% room air cardiac auscultation: regular heart rhythm, in 2 times, no murmurs heart rate: 8normal S1 and S2 per minute abdomen: globular, flaccid, bowel sounds, painless to superficial or deep palpation, no signs of peritoneal irritation. liver palpable 3 cm from the right costal margin, in the midclavicular line. extremities: warm and well perfused; capillary refill time less than 3 seconds; no edema or swelling of the calves. presence of ochre dermatitis on the lower limbs, with bilateral fibrous scars, without flapping pressure injury in the sacral region. discussed with [person]: we decided to discharge the patient after completing treatment for urinary tract infection by escherichia coli multis with a follow-up appointment visit on 1/17 at the gaf for reevaluation. we maintain medications in use during hospitalization. we provide guidance on warning signs. home care service sad for pressure injury care and home motor physiotherapy. good.

discharge_summary: admission: 10/06/2020, discharge: 11/11/2020, stay: 01 m 05 d 13 h, location: ward, payer: sus. [person], 48 years old, born and raised in {city}, 2 children, {omitted}, lives with {omitted}, studied until sixth grade, right hand dominance, problem: status epilepticus decompensation to be clarified infectious screening with no evident focus secondary to aspiration pneumonia, hypoglycemia? family member reports medication adherence, no history of drug interaction, cranial computed tomography 10/05: global atrophy left frontal calcification adjacent to subcortical hypodensity ntx? right frontal cortical and subcortical hypodensity without enhancement 10/07: transfer to intensive care unit 10/08: electroencephalogram 10/08: neurology suggests performing a computed tomography scan of the skull with venous phase contrast as soon as possible. 09/10: start of sedation weaning 09/10: increase in lamotrigine, uncharacteristic movements 10/10: change of antibiotic to meropenem 10/10: CT Angiography (CTA) of the chest and skull, pulmonary thromboembolism with 25% load, full anticoagulation started with enoxaparin 80 mg 12/12h on 10/11 12/10: hypotension, hypoxia, ETT (Endotracheal Tube) obstruction, start of neuromuscular blockade 12/10: abdominal distension, fasting until further notice, nasogastric tube in drainage, 600 ml in 24h, personal history: human immunodeficiency virus infection, diagnosis in 2000: undetectable CV: August/2020 CD4 904 August/2020 ART: AZT 3TC EFZ 2010. 08/2018 TDF 3tc dol depressive symptoms. neurotoxoplasmosis {omitted} left hemiparesis. sulfa drug use and ceftriaxone. seizures after traumatic brain injury and pneumococcal meningitis in 1998, prior to hcv treatment, it was proposed to change phenobarbital to lamotrigine. lamotrigine protocol opened without success. decided to prescribe clobazam in 2017, in use since consultation in 2017, when he had a seizure. since then he has not had new seizures, phenobarbital was discontinued on account of it. chronic hepatitis c genotype 1a treatment-nave: ahid follow-up. liver biopsy on 04/15: mild chronic hepatitis metavir a1/f1 rna hcv 2,922,831 august/2019 abdominal ultrasound: 04/18 incipient sonographic signs of chronic liver disease. depression without psychiatric follow-up. renewal of medication asid. continuous use medications valproic acid 250 mg 222 clonazepam 2.5 mg at night tdf 3tc dol sertraline 50 mg/day habits: smoker 1.5 pack/day since 12 years, chronic alcoholic, functionality: independent for basic activities, dependent for instrumental activities rankin 2, devices central venous catheter right internal jugular vein 05/10, orotracheal tube 05/10, indwelling urinary catheter 05/10, nasoenteral tube 05/10, antibiotics: current: meropenem 10/10 previous: ceftriaxone clindamycin d0 05/10 to 10/10 blood cultures 06/10: staphylococcus epidermidis 01 sample exams hospitalization: electroencephalogram 06/10: revealed abnormal, evidencing: moderate to marked diffuse disorganization of the background activity due to low amplitude of tracing rhythms, with a higher content of slow waves in the delta range, lack of physiological graphoelements of sleep, and absence of clinical and electroencephalographic reactivity to painful stimuli, however [person] presented spontaneous superficialization of consciousness during a short stretch of the tracing. electroclinical correlation: the findings are nonspecific and cannot rule out the effect of central nervous system depressant drugs. electroencephalogram 08/10: the marked symmetrical disorganization of the background activity due to diffuse and irregular slowing in the delta range, absence of physiological graphoelements of sleep and absence of electroencephalographic reactivity to painful stimuli noted intermittent modulation by low amplitude sinusoidal rhythms in the alpha/beta range. conclusion and electroclinical correlation: the electroencephalogram is abnormal. the findings are compatible with the effect of central nervous system depressant drugs, and associated encephalopathy cannot be ruled out.

discharge_summary: admission: 12/06, discharge: 12/21, stay: 14 d 11 h, location: ward, payer: sus. 1. heart failure profile c dobutamine on 12/07 and 12/08, 2. abscess in the left thigh, osteomyelitis in the pubis, fournier's syndrome, drainage on 12/03 with ultrasound and drain placement on 12/15, treatment with ceftriaxone guided by culture of abscess escherichia coli multi s colonized antibiotic therapy after shock, incision in intensive care unit on 12/17 with abundant purulent secretion, {omitted}. 3. septic shock from cutaneous urinary focus on 12/16 polymyxin d0 12/15 amikacin and vancomycin on 12/17, 4. chronic kidney disease acute dialysis by fistula on 12/16 5. cardiorespiratory arrest with pulseless electrical activity, 10 minutes after intubation report of previous bradycardia, follow-up appointment after 1 minute of cardiopulmonary resuscitation, 6. vt with pulse after cardiorespiratory arrest, effective electrical cardioversion with a shock. [person] presenting with instability in the last half hour, requiring norepinephrine elevation up to 1.5 mcg/kg/min. progresses with bradycardia, QRS widening, and worsening shock. Given the hyperkalemia even after hemodialysis, 2 ampoules of calcium gluconate and 100 ml of bicarbonate were administered, and the respiratory rate was increased on the ventilator in order to reduce pco2 and consequently k. 2 ampoules of atropine were administered without benefit. [person] progressed to asystolic cardiorespiratory arrest, {omitted} in refractory shock. I declare {omitted} dead, due to absence of central pulses, pupils in fixed mydriasis, absence of heart sounds and asytole on the monitor, as well as absence of brainstem reflexes. The body was released. I request contact with the family. I await the death certificate to be completed. Death. Drainage of Fournier's gangrene. Death.

discharge_summary: admission: 12/06, discharge: 12/21, stay: 14 d 11 h, location: ward, payer: sus. 1. heart failure profile c dobutamine on 12/07 and 12/08, 2. abscess in the left thigh, osteomyelitis in the pubis, fournier's syndrome, drainage on 12/03 with ultrasound and drain placement on 12/15, treatment with ceftriaxone guided by culture of abscess escherichia coli multi s colonized antibiotic therapy after shock, incision in intensive care unit on 12/17 with abundant purulent secretion, {omitted}. 3. septic shock from cutaneous urinary focus on 12/16 polymyxin d0 12/15 amikacin and vancomycin on 12/17, 4. chronic kidney disease acute dialysis by fistula on 12/16 5. cardiorespiratory arrest with pulseless electrical activity, 10 minutes after intubation report of previous bradycardia, follow-up appointment after 1 minute of cardiopulmonary resuscitation, 6. vt with pulse after cardiorespiratory arrest, effective electrical cardioversion with a shock. [person] presenting with instability in the last half hour, requiring norepinephrine elevation up to 1.5 mcg/kg/min. progresses with bradycardia, QRS widening, and worsening shock. Given the hyperkalemia even after hemodialysis, 2 ampoules of calcium gluconate and 100 ml of bicarbonate were administered, and the respiratory rate was increased on the ventilator in order to reduce pco2 and consequently k. 2 ampoules of atropine were administered without benefit. [person] progressed to asystolic cardiorespiratory arrest, {omitted} in refractory shock. I declare {omitted} dead, due to absence of central pulses, pupils in fixed mydriasis, absence of heart sounds and asytole on the monitor, as well as absence of brainstem reflexes. The body was released. I request contact with the family. I await the death certificate to be completed. Death. Drainage of Fournier's gangrene. Death.
